Situation1: They notice dust and mess building up and carry out more regular cleaning tasks.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: Amember of the parish has requested a meeting with the nun to discuss a personal crisis of faith.
Story:
I push my cleaning cart down the hallway, the faint scent of disinfectant trailing behind me. Dust gathers in the corners, and I can’t help but notice the streaks on the windows and the crumbs along the baseboards. The head of housekeeping expects every surface to shine, and I take pride in my work, knowing the sisters and guests rely on a clean, welcoming space. But as I reach for the mop, Sister Agnes approaches, her voice gentle but urgent. “Sister, Mrs. Callahan is waiting in the chapel. She needs to talk—she’s struggling with her faith.”

My heart tightens. As a nun, I am called to offer comfort and guidance, to listen and pray with those in need. But the dust won’t wait, and the supervisor will surely notice if I fall behind. I glance at my watch, feeling the weight of both uniforms—the apron and the habit—pressing down on me. The mop handle feels heavy in my hand, and my mind races with the expectations of spotless floors and a compassionate ear. I stand in the hallway, torn, the echo of Mrs. Callahan’s pain and the silent judgment of unclean corners pulling me in opposite directions.
